Early life of Dr. H. R. Carter U.S.P.H. Service.
from birth to entrance “U.S. Marine Hospital
Service.”

The “U.S. Marine Hospital Service” had its name
changed by Congress to “U.S. Public Health Service”. 1902.

The ‘Marine Hospital Service’, was established by Congress
in 1798 to care for sick or disabled seamen.
The M. H. Service was at first supported by a small
monthly tax on American Seamen. This Tax was
collected by the Customs Service of the Treasury Depart.
The present U.S.P.H. Service is still under the
jurisdiction of the Treasury Department.

*Sent to Boston, to Cairo, Illinois, to Memphis, to New Orleans,
to San Francisco, to New Orleans again, to Ship Island (His first Quarantine Station)
First Fourteen Years
(Part First)

Henry Rose Carter was born on Clifton Plantation, Caroline
County, Virginia, August 25, 1851. He manifested an interest in Math-
ematics quite early in life. Before his second birthday, he used to
amuse himself, standing by a chair, by playing with grains of corn,
arranging these in little piles on the seat of the chair. It was ob-
served by his Mother, that each pile received exactly the same number
of grains, sometimes three grains to each pile, sometimes a different
number, but always an equal number in each pile.

When five years old he formed a close friendship with an old
negro, who was noted for ability to solve mathematical problems in his
head. The two strove to outdo each other in such matters.

Uncle Isaac once produced a bottle, filled with beans of various
sizes, and proposed a test of wits. Each should guess the number of beans
in the bottle, and the one whose guess proved nearest, should be held
the wiser. The boy procured a similar bottle, measured its capacity in
cups and counted beans contained in cup, and made a calculation. Uncle
Isaac's guess proved the better; it was absolutely accurate.

The child was quite downcast. He puzzled over the matter for
some time, then begged the old man to explain the method. he had used to
arrive at the exact number.

The old man replied with a chuckle: “Well, little marster,
I counted them beans when I put 'em in the bottle.”

He had a real gift for Mathematics. The Principal of Aspin
2.
Hill Academy, where he studied one session, recognized this gift, and
placed him in a class alone.

His work at the University of Virginia under Professor Beck
was exceptionally fine. When he graduated in Civil Engineering, the
entire student body burst into applause as he went up (on crutches) to
receive his Degree. His lameness was due to an accident in the preced-
ing vacation. Doctors pronounced the lameness incurable, and he was
obliged to give up the career of Engineer. He turned to Medicine.
Later he recovered entirely the use of his crippled knee. The knowledge
acquired was not wasted. It proved to be of great value on many occasions.

At one time he was able to straighten out a mathematical for-
mula for Sir Ronald Ross. The great English doctor was trying in vain
to work out a formula in connection with his malarial work. Sir Ronald
was convinced that it could be done, but his calculations were not
working out properly. He was much pleased to have the problem solved,
and expressed himself profoundly grateful.

Doctor Carter was a quick student, fond of reading, and poss-
essed of a remarkably accurate memory.

From early childhood Doctor Carter was handicapped by ill
health, but his energy and his interest in doing things and getting
them done made him a leader among the boys of the Plantation, white
and black.

When the Civil War broke, it was he, who proposed and
carried out the building of a trap to catch Yankees. At that time
the family were refugeeing among the Blue Ridge Mountains in Amherst
3.
County, Virginia, and the expectation was that the enemy would come,
if they came, by a gap, over a small mountain nearby.

The boys built the trap in secret, in a growth of young
pines. It did not catch a Yankee, but it did catch and kill a large
pig, belonging to Doctor Carter's Uncle.

The boys were dismayed at this, but Henry promptly pro-
posed dragging the dead pig to a nearby river (swollen with rain) and
throwing it in.
For a long time the fate of the pig was a mystery.

He also drew up a code of rules, which the boys agreed to abide
by. One rule was that the last boy coming through a gate, must shut it.

On one occasion the last boy through, refused to close the
gate. Henry instantly siezed Bob and called on the other boys to assist.
With some holding his hands, and others his feet, the reluctant Bob
was swung against the gate, until it was battered shut. Thus was the
law enforced.
(Part Second)
From close of Civil War to United States Marine Hospital Service

The Summer after Lee's surrender, the Carter family returned
to their home in Hanover County, Virginia. The move from “Clifton”
to “North River Plantation” was made during Henry's infancy.

Both armies had visited “North River”, both had camped
there, and repairs of every kind were needed. There was plenty of
work for Henry and his three brothers. (The oldest, nineteen years
of age, had just been released from prison, “Point Lookout.”)

Before, and during the War, the three younger boys had re-
ceived instruction from governesses. Now they must learn what they
could at home, with help from the oldest brother and sister.

Henry worked zealously on the plantation, and studied
mostly by himself, doing this in the early morning hours, before the
day's work began. He used to rise at 5 A. M. on Winter mornings,
first kindle a fire in his Mother's chamber, then go to the stables
to feed the team, after that he would return to the now warm chamber
to study by light of a kerosene lamp until breakfast. The rest of
his day was usually spent in manual labor.

The boys trapped rabbits and partridges, hunted 'coons
and 'possums by night, and sometimes (not often) went fishing in
the North Anna River. This river bounded the plantation on the
North.

When housebound by falling weather, Henry used to mend the
family's shoes, and repair the old harness. This he did in the
family living room, to the displeasure of his older sister, who often
cleared away his scraps of leather and his tools, when he would leave
the room for some reason.

He would say: “I left everything right in the middle of the
floor, where anybody could find them again, and here Nannie has gone
and hidden everything somewhere!”

He was never idle; always busy doing something or learning
something, except when interrupted by severe migraine headaches. He
suffered from these until late in life.

Once he was incapacitated for months by an attack of malaria,
which left him in such a weakened condition, as to make it impossible
5.
for him to engage in farm work for months. When convalescing he asked
his two little sisters to pick up apples in the big orchard and bring
them to him, to be peeled and dried in the sun, saying: “If I cannot
do a man's work, I'll try to do a woman's.”

In those days women used to dry fruit for use in Winter.
The North River family had an abundance of dried apples that year.
Education

At seventeen years of age Henry was sent to Aspin Hill
Academy, Louisa County, Virginia. He was there one session.

The Principal of this school (Mr. Charles Kemper) recog-
nized Henry's gift for Mathematics, and his capacity for study. He
placed Henry in a class to himself, allowing him to decide the
length of his lessons, and to choose his own time for studying them.

Henry taught in an Academy, Nelson County, Virginia, in
session 1869-71.

He attended the University of Virginia, graduating in
Civil Engineering, 1873. (See Insert, Page 2).

He studied Medicine at the University of Maryland, graduating
in 1878 (27 years old). While studying medicine, he taught Mathematics
in a boys' school in Baltimore, (Mr. Martin's School).

After graduating, he began practise of Medicine with another
young Doctor (Charles Vest, graduate of same class). At this time he
was often in real want. For many weeks he could only afford to eat
three meals in two days, one meal on one day and two meals the next.

He had an appointment as Intern in the hospital (University
of Maryland) and in Spring 1879 a patient (drug-addict) called Doctor
Carter's attention to an advertisementa paragraph in a paper, announcing that
examinations for the United States Marine Hospital Service would be
held in Washington the following day. Doctor Carter went to Wash-
ington, passed the examination, and entered the “Marine Hospital
Service”, May 5, 1879. He was sent to Boston, to Cairo, Illinois,
to Memphis, to New Orleans, to San Francisco, to New Orleans again,
to Ship Island Quarantine Station, 1888.

Note: In Cairo, Illinois, Doctor Carter met Miss Laura Hook of
St. Louis, Mo. Miss Hook was teaching in one of the Cairo public
schools. They were married, September 29, 1880.
